Quiz 1 Solution (StatComp 2021/22)

Finn Lindgren

Source: vignettes/articles/Quiz1Solution.Rmd
Quiz1Solution.Rmd

Deriving the Hessian

Define the individual terms as fk=yklog(1+eâˆ’Î·k)+(Nâˆ’yk)log(1+eÎ·k)f_k=y_k\log(1+e^{-\eta_k}) + (N-y_k)\log(1+e^{\eta_k}), so that f=âˆ‘k=1nfkf=\sum_{k=1}^n f_k. We know that âˆ‚Î·k/âˆ‚Î¸1â‰¡1\partial\eta_k/\partial\theta_1\equiv 1 and âˆ‚Î·k/âˆ‚Î¸2=k\partial\eta_k/\partial\theta_2=k. Then the derivatives with respect to Î¸1\theta_1 and Î¸2\theta_2 can be obtain with the chain rule: dfkdÎ¸i=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸iâˆ‚fkâˆ‚Î·k=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸i[ykâˆ’eâˆ’Î·k1+eâˆ’Î·k+(Nâˆ’yk)eÎ·k1+eÎ·k]=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸i[ykâˆ’eâˆ’Î·k/2eÎ·k/2+eâˆ’Î·k/2+(Nâˆ’yk)eÎ·k/2eâˆ’Î·k/2+eÎ·k/2]=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸i[âˆ’ykeâˆ’Î·k/2+eÎ·k/2eÎ·k/2+eâˆ’Î·k/2+N1eâˆ’Î·k+1]=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸i[Neâˆ’Î·k+1âˆ’yk]\begin{align*} \frac{df_k}{d\theta_i} &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \frac{\partial f_k}{\partial\eta_k} \\ &= \frac{\partial \eta_k}{\partial \theta_i} \left[ y_k \frac{-e^{-\eta_k}}{1+e^{-\eta_k}} + (N-y_k) \frac{e^{\eta_k}}{1+e^{\eta_k}} \right] \\ &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \left[ y_k \frac{-e^{-\eta_k/2}}{e^{\eta_k/2}+e^{-\eta_k/2}} + (N-y_k) \frac{e^{\eta_k/2}}{e^{-\eta_k/2}+e^{\eta_k/2}} \right] \\ &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \left[ - y_k \frac{e^{-\eta_k/2}+e^{\eta_k/2}}{e^{\eta_k/2}+e^{-\eta_k/2}} + N \frac{1}{e^{-\eta_k}+1} \right] \\ &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \left[ \frac{N}{e^{-\eta_k}+1} - y_k \right] \\ \end{align*} Since the derivatives of Î·k\eta_k with respect to Î¸1\theta_1 and Î¸2\theta_2 do not depend on the values of Î¸1\theta_1 and Î¸2\theta_2, the second order derivatives are d2fkdÎ¸idÎ¸j=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸iâˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸jâˆ‚âˆ‚Î·k[Neâˆ’Î·k+1âˆ’yk]=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸iâˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸jNeâˆ’Î·k(eâˆ’Î·k+1)2=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸iâˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸jN(eâˆ’Î·k/2+eÎ·k/2)2=âˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸iâˆ‚Î·kâˆ‚Î¸jN4cosh(Î·k/2)2\begin{align*} \frac{d^2f_k}{d\theta_i d\theta_j} &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_j} \frac{\partial}{\partial\eta_k}\left[ \frac{N}{e^{-\eta_k}+1} - y_k \right] \\ &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_j} \frac{N e^{-\eta_k}}{(e^{-\eta_k}+1)^2} \\ &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_j} \frac{N}{(e^{-\eta_k/2}+e^{\eta_k/2})^2} \\ &= \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_i} \frac{\partial\eta_k}{\partial\theta_j} \frac{N}{4\cosh(\eta_k/2)^2} \\ \end{align*} Plugging in the Î¸\theta-derivatives gives the Hessain contribution for term fkf_k as N4cosh(Î·k/2)2[1kkk2]. \frac{N}{4\cosh(\eta_k/2)^2} \begin{bmatrix}1 & k \\ k & k^2\end{bmatrix} .

Positive definite Hessian

To show that the total Hessian for ff is positive definite for nâ‰¥2n \geq 2, we define vectors ğ®k=[1k]\boldsymbol{u}_k=\begin{bmatrix}1 \\ k\end{bmatrix} and dk=N4cosh(Î·k/2)2d_k=\frac{N}{4\cosh(\eta_k/2)^2}. Define the 2-nn matrix ğ”=[ğ®1ğ®2â‹¯ğ®n]\boldsymbol{U}=\begin{bmatrix}\boldsymbol{u}_1 & \boldsymbol{u}_2 & \cdots & \boldsymbol{u}_n\end{bmatrix} and a diagonal matrix ğƒ\boldsymbol{D} with Dii=diD_{ii}=d_i. The product ğ”ğƒğ”âŠ¤\boldsymbol{U}\boldsymbol{D}\boldsymbol{U}^\top is then another way of writing the Hessian for ff. Since all the vectors ğ®k\boldsymbol{u}_k are non-parallel, and the did_i are strictly positive for all combinations of Î¸1\theta_1 and Î¸2\theta_2, this matrix has full rank (rank 2) for nâ‰¥2n \geq 2, and is positive definite.

Alternative reasoning

The Hessian for each fkf_k is positive semi-definite, since it can be written dkğ®kğ®kâŠ¤d_k\boldsymbol{u}_k\boldsymbol{u}_k^\top for some dk>0d_k > 0 and vector ğ®k\boldsymbol{u}_k. The sum of a positive definite matrix and a positive semi-definite matrix is positive definite, so itâ€™s sufficient to prove that the sum of the first two terms is positive definite. For any positive scaling constant ww, the determinant of [1111]+w[1224] \begin{bmatrix}1 & 1\\1 & 1\end{bmatrix}+w\begin{bmatrix}1 & 2\\2 & 4\end{bmatrix} is (1+w)(1+4w)âˆ’(1+2w)2=1+5w+4w2âˆ’1âˆ’4wâˆ’4w2=w>0(1+w)(1+4w)-(1+2w)^2=1+5w+4w^2-1-4w-4w^2=w > 0. this means that any (positively) weighted sum of those two matrices is positive definite (since each is positive semi-definite, and a positive determinant rules ot the sum being only positive semi-definite). This proves that the total Hessian is positive definite for nâ‰¥2n\geq 2.

Remark

Note that in the first proof of positive definiteness, we didnâ€™t actually need to know the specific values of the ğ®k\boldsymbol{u}_k vectors, that are proportional to the gradients fo Î·k\eta_k with respect to ğ›‰=(Î¸1,Î¸2)\boldsymbol{\theta}=(\theta_1,\theta_2); it was sufficient that they were non-parallel, ensuring that ğ”\boldsymbol{U} had full rank. This means that any linear model for Î·k\eta_k in a set of parameters ğ›‰=(Î¸1,â€¦,Î¸p)\boldsymbol{\theta}=(\theta_1,\dots,\theta_p) leads to a positive definite Hessian for this model, if the collection of gradient vectors of (Î·1,â€¦,Î·n)(\eta_1,\dots,\eta_n) with respect to ğ›‰\boldsymbol{\theta} have collective rank at least pp.
